headline: WHO re-elects Ghebreyesus as DG for second term
summarized_story:
Member States of the World Health Organisation have re-elected Dr. Tedros Ghebreyesus to serve a second five-year term as the organisation’s Director-General.
According to a news release posted on its official website on Tuesday, the organisation’s governing body affirmed Ghebryesus’ re-appointment as the head of the organisation, during its ongoing 75th World Health Assembly held in Geneva, Switzerland.
In his remark after to his re-election, Ghebreyesus said, “I am humbled by the opportunity provided by the member states to serve a second term as WHO Director-General.
It also said his new mandate would officially commence on August 16, 2022, and end in 2027, as ‘’a Director-General can be re-appointed once, in accordance with World Health Assembly rules and procedures’’.
‘’Before first being appointed WHO Director-General, Dr Tedros served as Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ethiopia from 2012–2016 and as Minister of Health, Ethiopia from 2005–2012.

headline: I’ll change nature of Nigeria’s politics, says Hayatu-deen
summarized_story:
A presidential aspirant on the platform of the Peoples Democratic Party, Mohammed Hayatu-Deen, has said career politicians were recycling themselves and running Nigeria aground.
According to a statement on Tuesday, Hayatu-deen, who spoke at an interactive session with the media, however, said his venture into the country’s politics was to change its character.
He expressed the optimism that he can clinch the PDP presidential ticket while citing examples of people who rose to leadership positions without holding any political position in the past.
“Career politicians are recycling themselves and running the country into the ground.
“My aim is to change the character and complexion of our politics.

summarized_story:

headline: ASUU strike: US calls for creative ways to fund Nigerian varsities
summarized_story:
By Ebunoluwa SessouAs the ASUU strike enters its 13th week, U.S educational experts have called on Nigerian universities to look outside the government for the funding of their institutions.
One of the U.S. higher education experts, Dr. Patrick Bennett, vice-president of Academic Quality and Planning at Franklin University, Ohio, shared the U.S perspective on higher education partnerships and funding.
Dr. Bennett discussed best practices in exploring potential revenue streams and resources outside of government funding for higher education and how universities can build and maintain productive relationships with alumni, private sector, and other donor institutions.
The U.S Mission has a longstanding commitment to supporting educational institutions and strengthening an education system that enables students to access quality education throughout Nigeria.
The move by the U.S Consulate-General was to collaborate with Nigerian universities – both public and private – especially as funding to seek foreign education has remained uncertain for Nigerian families.

headline: IOPC Fund harps on progress, worry over non-submission of report by Nigeria
summarized_story:
By Eguono OdjegbaThe National Standing Committee, NSC, on International Oil Pollution Compensation, IOPC, Fund implementation in Nigeria has said Nigeria is upbeat about her plans to submit names of Contributing Oil Receivers to the IOPC Fund, to enable the organization have the right data to work with.
Jeddah expressed satisfaction about the immense work done by the Sub-Committees, including Nigeria’s commitment towards effective implementation of the IOPC Funds.
She noted that as a member of the IOPC Fund, Nigeria cannot afford to be unconcerned about the international convention which she said has been domesticated by Nigeria.
She stated: “Nigeria is a party to the International Convention for Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1992 and the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage 1992.
Also speaking, Chairperson, Sub Committee on Pricing Index, Mrs. Oma Ofodile, expressed the belief that sensitisation of oil receiving organisations would culminate in mass registration and contribution towards the IOPC Fund.

headline: NCC committed to promoting organisational efficiency, capacity building – Danbatta
summarized_story:
The Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) has once again reiterated its stance on professionalizing its workforce and strengthening collaborations with strategic partners such as the Nigerian Institute of Management (NIM) in order to enhance operational efficiency.
The Executive Vice Chairman (EVC) of NCC Prof. Umar Danbatta, stated this while receiving a delegation led by the Acting Registrar and CEO of NIM, Jude Iheanacho, who paid a courtesy visit to the NCC Head Office recently.
Malah also said that it was in the Commission’s best interest to deepen its collaboration with NIM, through strategic partnering, so that NCC can improve organisational efficiency and regulatory excellence.
The Nigerian Institute of Management (NIM) was established in 1961, though the enabling Act, the Nigerian Institute of Management (Establishment) Act was enacted by the National Assembly on July 19, 2003.
The objectives of the institute include the development of good management, professionalizing management, and improving and standardizing management in Nigeria.

headline: 2023 presidency: Buhari’s body language favours South – Umahi

headline: Fatima: Fani-Kayode reacts to killing of pregnant woman, four children in South-East
summarized_story:
A former Aviation Minister, Femi Fani-Kayode, on Tuesday condemned the killing of a pregnant woman identified as Fatima, her four children and six others in Anambra State.
The victims, who are of northern extraction, were reportedly killed at Isulo, Orumba North Local Government Area of the state, on Sunday.
He also called on the authority to treat those who committed this atrocity as a beast.
He tweeted: “The killing of a heavily pregnant northern lady by the name of Fatima together with her 4 children and 6 others in Anambra State by unknown gunmen is shameful & barbaric.

headline: 2023: Police ban political thuggery, use of weapons during primary elections in Jigawa
summarized_story:
The Nigeria Police force have banned political thuggery and use of any weapon especially during the conduct of the political parties primary elections.
This was contained in a statement signed by the police Spokesman, Jigawa State command, ASP Lawan Shiisu Adam issued to DAILY POST.
According to the statement, “Sequel to the forthcoming primary elections in the state, the Commissioner of Police, Jigawa state Police Command CP.
Aliyu Sale Tafida psc, wishes to remind political parties and their followers in the state, that the ban on political thuggery, use of weapons such as; cutlasses, sticks, bow and arrows, guns, machetes, jack knives and other dangerous weapons, during political primaries is still enforced.”He urged political actors to advise their followers to refrain from such and strictly adhere and abide by the rules and regulation governing the electoral processes.
He explained that the police will not hesitate to arrest anybody who wishes to use the opportunity to foment trouble and violate the provision of the law as contained in the electoral act and regulations.

headline: 17.7m fully vaccinated against COVID-19, says Fed Govt
summarized_story:
The Federal Government yesterday disclosed that over 17.7 million Nigerians are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 pandemic, representing 15.8 per cent of the eligible population.
It said as of May 24, 29,651,708 eligible persons have received the 1st dose of the COVID-19 vaccines, which represents 23.4 per cent of the country’s eligible population, while 14,179,966 people have received the second dose.
It said 1,178,604 people have received the booster dose of the vaccine.
The Executive Director of the National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA), Dr. Faisal Shuaib, made this known in Abuja while receiving four million, four hundred thousand (4,400,000) doses of Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccines donated by the Government of Spain.
The single-dose regimen of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine will enable us to move rapidly towards achieving herd immunity.

headline: FAKE NEWS ALERT: No plane crash in Lagos, says FAAN
summarized_story:
The Federal Airports Authority of Nigeria (FAAN) has denied reports making the rounds that a plane crashed at Ikeja area of Lagos state.
Several reports surfaced on Tuesday that a plane crash-landed in Ikeja, and the incident was said to have caused heavy traffic in the area.
However, in a statement issued on Tuesday night, the agency said while an aircraft was spotted in the area, it was being transported to a different location, and wasn’t the result of a crash.
“The Federal Airports Authority of Nigeria would like to inform the general public to disregard the news making the rounds on social media about an alleged crash at Ikeja Airport,” the statement reads.
Advertisement“The aircraft was sold by the owner to a buyer, who was taking it to its final destination.”

headline: Can proptech solve Nigeria’s urbanisation crisis?
summarized_story:

headline: Nigeria to generate over ₦90 billion annually from new phone call tax
summarized_story:
The Nigerian government has created a new tax on phone calls in the bid to fund free healthcare for Nigerian citizens who cannot afford healthcare—the vulnerable group.
The law defines the “vulnerable group” in society as “Children under five, pregnant women, aged, physically and mentally challenged persons, and indigent people as may be defined from time to time”.
The law also requires that all persons resident in Nigeria are expected to obtain health insurance.
Nigerians made 150.83 billion minutes of calls in 2020 according to a report by the Nigerian Communications Commission.
This translates to 9.05 trillion seconds of calls, meaning the new tax will generate at least 9.05 trillion Kobo, which converts to ₦90.49 billion ($18.09 million), annually.

headline: Rivers Governor, Nyesom Wike, dissolves cabinet, COS, Others sacked -
summarized_story:
Rivers State Governor, Nyesom Ezenwo Wike, has announced the dissolution of the State Executive Council.
The statement read “The Chief of Staff to the governor and Senior Special Assistant (Protocol), have also been relieved of their office.
“His Excellency, Governor Nyesom Ezenwo Wike, commends the members the Rivers State Executive Council for their service and contribution to the development of the State.
He was also a local government Chairman in Rivers State and has always touted his experience at all levels of government as one that has prepared him for the highest office in the Land.
Governor Nyesom Wike’s tenure will end in 2023.

headline: Zulum hosts APC presidential aspirant TS Jack-Rich
summarized_story:
Borno State Governor, Babagana Zulum said the people of Borno State are appreciative of the visible footprints and humanitarian strides of a frontline Presidential Aspirant of the All Progressives Congress, Tein T.S.
Jack-Rich, in the state.
Governor Zulum disclosed this at the government House Maiduguri while hosting an APC Presidential Aspirant and his entourage who were on a consultative visit to the state to meet with Stakeholders and Delegates of the Party ahead of the Presidential Primaries.
The Borno State Governor notes with gratitude the people-oriented projects executed by Mr Jack-Rich in parts of the State which includes world-class Potable Water Facilities of 250,000 Litre Capacity each at Gonidangari and Shehuri North in Maiduguri as well as the ongoing ultra-modern Faculty of Engineering and 180-Bed capacity Hotel projects at the Nigerian Army University in Biu.
On his part the Presidential aspirant Jack-Rich vowes to address the problems militating against the ease of doing business in Borno in order to attract private sector investments if he emerged as President in 2023.

headline: Bode George: PDP Primaries Are In Line With INEC’s Procedures
summarized_story:
It has been different strokes for different aspirants at the ongoing Peoples Democratic Party primaries across the country.
In the Federal Capital Territory Abuja, incumbent senator representing the FCT, Senator Philip Aduda, emerged the winner of the People’s Democratic Party senate primaries.
In Enugu, there were huge losses with Deputy Minority Leader of the House of Reps, Toby Okechukwu, losing his bid to return to the green chamber.
In Aramoko Ekiti, Lere Olayinka defeated Victor Adeyinka in the Reps primary poll, a situation which didn’t go down well with Adeyinka’s supporters.
Our guest is Chief Bode George, Former Deputy National Chairman, South West of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP)

headline: Unknown Gunmen Attack Anambra + Buhari Visits Kano Explosion Victims – Trending With Ojy Okpe
summarized_story:
Following the insecurity crisis in Anambra state; A former Minister of Education, Oby Ezekwesili, called on the National Assembly on Thursday to invite President Muhammadu Buhari to account for insecurity in the country.
In the meantime, Seven persons including a mother and four of her children were killed by unknown gunmen in Anambra state.
Meanwhile The Anambra Police Command has alleged that some communities in the state are shielding criminals attacking, killing and maiming innocent people.
Finally, President Muhammadu Buhari on Thursday condoled with the victims of the recent explosion in Kano state.

headline: Based On Supreme Court Judgement, I Am The APGA Chairman – Edozie Njoku
summarized_story:
National Chairman, All Progressives Grand Alliance, APGA, Victor Oye has dismissed claims by some individuals purportedly identifying as a faction of the party, maintaining that APGA has no faction in Anambra State.
In his submission, Oye described “Edozie Njoku” as an impostor saying his role and attempts to obtain a forged judgment were “sacrilegious”.
It will be recalled that Njoku was sacked as APGA’s national chairman by the lower court in Jigawa State, and lost at the appellate court afterwards.
Based on unfolding events, the former National Vice Chairman of the party, Edozie Njoku, told newsmen in Abuja that an FCT High Court has pronounced him the new National Chairman of APGA after a judgement.
Our guest is APGA Factional Chairman, Chief Edozie Njoku.

headline: Bode George: Who Owns Alpha-Beta
summarized_story: Bode George responds to Bayo Onanuga, a Campaign Spokesman for Presidential Aspirant Bola Ahmed Tinubu, who last week referred to Bode Georgie as a ‘perpetual political failure, who is diminished by Tinubu, and rejected by Lagosians’

headline: UK PM Johnson Facing Fresh Criticism after New Partygate Photos Emerge
summarized_story:
Boris Johnson is facing fresh questions after photos showing the prime minister drinking at an event during a Covid lockdown were published.
The pictures, released by ITV News, are believed to show the prime minister at a leaving party on 13 November 2020.
The Metropolitan Police are facing calls to explain why Mr Johnson did not receive a fine.
A government source told BBC News the photos may have been taken by the official No 10 photographer and proved Mr Johnson was there in a work capacity.
Mr Johnson is pictured toasting colleagues while standing by a table laden with wine bottles, wine glasses, food and other drinks.
